comments.content: Try an emboldened **[Beaumarchais](http://web.archive.org/web/20140405001734/http:/www.findmyfont.com/index.php/fonts/font-preview?fset=Scriptorium-Fonts&ffam=Beaumarchais%20-%20Regular&fid=ace24d9011a3a90be6ecd3fccf027c91&fstyle=b&fsize=60&text=TONIGHTS&fit=1)** by David F. Nalle [1993, Scriptorium Fonts]
That's the one, thank you so very much.

I prefer the David Nalle's upright font to this laid back leftie. Anyway, my purpose for posting is to ask if anyone has any idea what David Nalle used as a source?  
Don

Don, see also these posts on Beaumarchais a.k.a. Columbus:  
 [http://typophile.com/node/33604](http://web.archive.org/web/20140405001734/http:/typophile.com/node/33604 "http://typophile.com/node/33604")  
 [http://typophile.com/node/18024](http://web.archive.org/web/20140405001734/http:/typophile.com/node/18024 "http://typophile.com/node/18024")

Thanks Fivos. I knew this was familiar! Overload at the memory bank! One of the more famous fonts by Hermann Ihlenburg, patented November 29, 1892.  
 Notes from Solopedia  
----start quote----  
(Sam Wang, Brendel/B&PGraphics), Wedgewood (Brendel), Deneane (FontBank), Cowan (Opti), C790 Deco (Softmaker), Tringle (WSI), Jazzy 50 (Fantazia), Beaumarchais (Scriptorium)  
Tom Phinney is developing a high-quality version named Cristoforo.  
----end quote---  
Tom Phinny's update:  
 [http://www.thomasphinney.com/2014/01/kerning-and-spacing-fonts/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140405001734/http:/www.thomasphinney.com/2014/01/kerning-and-spacing-fonts/ "http://www.thomasphinney.com/2014/01/kerning-and-spacing-fonts/")  
Don

BTW for the record, the correct font ID is clearly "Columbus." All the others are derivative.  
Don
